title.narrative: PRIDE / Region West Africa

description.narrative: Working towards diverse and inclusive societies in which LGBTI are able to participate to their full potential in some countries in West Africa

activity-date.narrative: Empowered LGBTI and Strong LGBTI community: In one of the countries we work with a new and emerging LGBT community, the whole strategy focuses on the level of empowerment of individuals and communities. We are supporting activities like soccer plays and cooking sessions in order to gather different communities : LGBTI communities, LBQ women, transwomen, transmen. Bringing people together is taken as a first step in building mutual trust and recognition. Also in other countries in the region individual empowerment and community building remain important interventions COC supports with partners, this forms the basis for stronger LGBT organisations and community-led advocacy work. Capable CBO: We support in each country the reinforcement of capacities of organisations which have a potential to have an impact on a national level. Capacity development is based on a more formal or informal capacity needs assessment analysis. Besides capacity development of (contractual) partners, COC includes other organisations in the process, reinforcing them within for example national LGBTI platforms or networks. COC is supporting the development of the West African Trans Forum as an organisation and network. COC is also supporting LBQT organisations in 4 Anglophone West African countries to implement a research into mental health, quality of life, violence and service accessibility. Mobilised LGBTI movement: West Africa is characterized by the underrepresentation of inclusive LGBTI groups, lesbian, bisexual and queer women and trans communities. The aim of the West African regional strategy is to strengthen those groups by strengthening networks on a regional level and collecting data which were lacking until now. 6 regional meetings have taken place so far 7 to engage the process: one for Francophone LBQ women, two for Anglophone LBQ women, three for trans people both Anglophone and Francophone. Within the countries, there is an effort to reinforce national networks. In 3 of the four countries these national networks are established. In the emerging county mentioned above we are still working on this. Global HR movement: The engagement in global L&A mechanism is generally very low in West Africa. A training coordinated by PAI and COC was given on a regional level in July 2017 in Ghana and provided tools to engage in several Human Rights mechanism. Following this training, two coalitions of LGBTI organizations in one of the focus countries have submitted a shadow report for the UPR 2018. One country participated in the 2017 UPR process.

title.narrative: 2018 Q2 IATI PRIDE West Africa
Capable Community Based Organisations.

description.narrative: Capable LGBTI organisations are essential in terms of supporting individual LGBTI people, giving a voice to the LGBTI community and aligning with different players in the broader LGBTI movement. They need to function at an “operational minimum” before they can start doing advocacy effectively.

title.narrative: DD5 DD5: Number of CBOs improving their capacities under PRIDE.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. This indicator measures all unique organisations who underwent a training on organisational development, financial management, L&A and/or were supported to attend events or conferences where they built on their skills through participation and engagement. Note that this indicator also counts those organisations not funded by PRIDE but are trained by partners in-country.

comment.narrative: 147 organisations were part of capacity building trajectories in West Africa. 88 of them were involved in governance and leadership skills building, 55 on sustainable revenue streams and 98 were part of skills development on lobby and advocacy.

title.narrative: Mobilised LGBTI Movement.

description.narrative: LGBTI organisations need to cooperate to reach their joint goals, while also respecting their diversity. Change starts when they connect, begin exchanging information and become a mobilised LGBTI movement. It is when they are linked to non-LGBTI stakeholders and to broader civil society organisations that change becomes possible in society.

title.narrative: DD3 DD3: Number of targeted actors adopting LGBTI and SOGIESC friendly terminology, rhetoric and framing.

description.narrative: On the basis of the initiatives carried out under indicator 10, this indicator measures successful adoption of terminology, rhetoric and framing on LGBTI/SOGIESC issues by those targeted.

comment.narrative: Of the total advocacy activities undertaken 83 resulted in successful outcomes, with the highest success rates in health advocacy. Reassurances and positive behaviours from 8 chief-doctors, 20 health service providers and 25 mediators were in the favour of LGBTI patients. 11 journalists used objective reporting terms when writing for newspapers and 7 initiatives of advocacy with parliamentarians also had a good result where they were able to make contributions to inclusive policy.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of advocacy initiatives carried out by grassroots organisations, community based organisations and CSOs to improve, change or influence relevant laws, policies and/or societal norms.

description.narrative: CBOs and activists supported through PRIDE hold causeries, dialogues, sensitisation trainings and the likes on various topics related to being LGBTI, SOGIESC, inclusive service provision, discriminatory biases in public practices etc. These initiatives are held with various stakeholders (religious leaders, service providers, schools, police, local governments and ministries). The aim of these dialogues is to sensitise the targeted actors on LGBTI and SOGIESC issues, and change/improve or influence their actions. Through this indicator, we measure how many such initiatives have been undertaken. This indicator does not encompass advocacy activities carried out at international spaces such as the UN, UPR etc. but only in-country/regional level engagement.

comment.narrative: In 2018, 109 advocacy actions were undertaken in West Africa, which included 60 targeted at service providers. These actions included meetings with chief doctors in multiple regions, service providers and mediators as well as with hospitals. 22 advocacy actions were aimed at media actors with journalists (using the HIV link), RADHO and other stakeholders for inclusive reporting. 13 actions at political actors and government officials of the countries in the region were undertaken, with the main targets the ministry of health and parliamentarians. 4 imams were also included in opening dialogues on LGBTI. Other actions of advocacy towards society actors included speaking with influential 'mamas' who hold immense power in west african societies.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of times unique alliances between different organisations were formed.

description.narrative: Grassroots organisations, CBOs and other CSOs come together for multiple reasons in order to cooperate and/or align efforts with broader movements - human rights, LGBTI, women's rights, etc. In some instances these cooperations manifest in the way of joint pressure campaigns on governments and research undertakings or through network expansion in remote areas of the country. For the LGBTI movement this helps build and grow a base of allies outside the community and also to increase visibility and develop solidarity with cross-cutting intersectional issues. This indicator measures the number of times unique alliances of two or more partners other relevant organisations and/or actors were formed.

comment.narrative: in 2018, there were 19 instances of collaboration between different organisations and networks in the region. This held significance as it allowed the movement to gain visibility and build momentum within the community in the region.

title.narrative: Empowered LGBTI Individuals

description.narrative: Social change starts with individual LGBTI people who no longer accept being marginalised but decide to take action. Individual stories raise public awareness and expose the level of exclusion in society. Empowered LGBTI individuals serve as role models for others, and their actions form important steps in the creation of LGBTI communities.

title.narrative: Number of LGBTI and allies, community members, service deliverers, and/or leaders educated and sensitised on LGBTI issues, who can carry forward the messages further.

description.narrative: CBOs and activists supported through PRIDE hold causeries, dialogues, sensitisation trainings and the likes on various topics related to being LGBTI, SOGIESC, inclusive service provision, discriminatory biases in public practices, self-esteem and acceptance etc. Through this indicator, we measure how many people have been reached through these initiatives.

title.narrative: Number of promotional actions undertaken by organisations to reach their constituency.

description.narrative: Promotions of their events, flyers of their organisations etc. are counted as promotional actions. These actions are solely undertaken to inform the community of the presence of the organisation.

comment.narrative: 54 promotional activities were undertaken allowing the partners to expand their reach, their base and raise awareness for their constituency on their presence in the country.

title.narrative: Number of knowledge dissemination activities taken on to bring the LGBTI community together, sensitise and inform them on their legal rights, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression and sex characteristics.

description.narrative: This indicator measures the number of knowledge dissemination tools (eg. legal handbooks) created and distributed, activities held (eg. soccer games, cooking classes etc.) amongst the community to inform, sensitise and/or educate them on relevant issues. These activities can be under the pretext of self-esteem building, empowerment trainings and the tools serve the purpose of awareness raising and information sharing within the community.

comment.narrative: 180 knowledge dissemination activities took place in the region, including social events, community dialogues development and launches of handbook for LGBTI.

title.narrative: Strong LGBTI Communities.

description.narrative: Strong communities start when front liners take action and bring individuals together. Communities start as small-scale social events and are often based on positive drivers: contact, entertainment or a shared interest. Creating a safe space is essential in starting communities.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of crisis response measures taken up.

description.narrative: At certain unfortunate moments, there arises a need for emergency and crisis response measures to be taken up by the LGBTI community in countries. These responses, while not a planned intervention under PRIDE, are supported by COC with the goal of building resilience within the community and extending solidarity in dire times of need. These responses include public statements issued, back-door diplomacy with embassies on the ground, emergency shelter provision, legal-aid services, medical and psychological help and provision of basic services such as food and water. Through this indicator we measure the number of such responses that have been deployed both by COC and its partners. (

comment.narrative: In two countries under this region, 73 cases were catered to in 2018. These cases involved responses to arbitrary arrests, detentions by police and relocation of rejected LGBTI people.

title.narrative: Number of safe spaces created.

description.narrative: Physical shelter creation in-country for LGBTI individuals to gather, exchange and/or seek safety.

comment.narrative: 2 shelters were opened, one with a regional reach and one within a country which was able to cater to 5 Trans people in need of shelter and emergency care.

title.narrative: Number of events the LGBTI community hosted/participated in.

description.narrative: Using public spaces to raise awareness and visibility of LGBTI issues is an effective way to mobilise, build communities and make public statements. Being visible publicly in many countries is in itself a significant achievement due to threats posed by social and political climates. This indicator measures the number of times the LGBTI community was supported in being publicly visible through events such as Pride, IDAHOT, Women's Day, Carnival etc.

comment.narrative: In 2018, the different partners in the regions were able to organise and participate in 10 public events for awareness raising and community mobilisation around important days such as Pride and IDAHOT.
